o: Process of restructuring existing computer code without changing its external behavior

Ritualistic inclusion of code or structures that serve no real purpose
Embedding data directly into the source code instead of using external sources
Storing distinct values in external resources (config files, DB)
Over-analyzing or over-designing without starting to write code
Disproportionate weight given to trivial issues (like color of the bikeshed) versus complex ones
A series of small tasks that must be done before one can do what one originally set out to do
Adding features or refinements that were not requested or necessary
Tendency to reinvent the wheel instead of using existing libraries
Problems with software libraries being incompatible or conflicting
Complications arising from working with dynamic link libraries (version conflicts)
Classloading issues in Java due to version mismatches
An interface with too many methods (Interface Segregation Principle violation)
A class that tries to do everything (complex, low cohesion)
Code that has no parent/caller (Dead Code)
Behavior is dependent on the sequence or timing of uncontrollable events
A software bug that seems to disappear or alter its behavior when one attempts to study it
When developers are afraid to change code because it breaks easily (fragile)

q: What is 'Test Driven Development' relationship to refactoring?
o: TDD guarantees a test suite exists, making refactoring safe and part of the cycle
Writing the Readme/API documentation first to design the interface clearly

q: What is 'Behavior Driven Development' relation to refactoring?
o: Ensures behavior is preserved from a user perspective during refactoring

q: What is 'Code Review' role in refactoring?
o: Peers can spot code smells and suggest refactorings before code is merged

q: What is 'Pair Programming' role in refactoring?
o: Continuous code review and refactoring on the fly
The whole team works on the same thing, at the same time, on the same computer
A tool specifically designed to help perform refactorings automatically (like Smalltalk env)
IDE features that safely perform standard refactorings (Rename, Extract) without manual editing
It is usually safer and faster than manual typing, handling references correctly
Code that is easy to understand and easy to change

q: Who wrote the book 'Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code'?

o: Software entities should be open for extension, but closed for modification
Subtypes must be substitutable for their base types
Clients should not be forced to depend on methods they do not use
High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules; both should depend on abstractions
Single responsibility, Open-closed, Liskov substitution, Interface segregation, Dependency inversion

q: How does SRP (Single Responsibility Principle) relate to refactoring?
o: Many refactorings (Extract Class/Method) aim to achieve SRP
The degree to which the elements inside a module belong together
The degree of interdependence between software modules

q: What is the goal of software design regarding Coupling and Cohesion?

o: Changing one component does not affect others (independence)
An operation that can be applied multiple times without changing the result beyond the initial application
A function modifying some state outside its local environment
A function where the return value is only determined by its input values, with no side effects

q: Which refactoring helps create Pure Functions?

o: An expression can be replaced by its corresponding value without changing the program's behavior
Every method should either be a command that performs an action, or a query that returns data, but not both
